description: Individually identifiable health information transmitted or maintained in electronic form; includes all health data that can be linked to an individual including patient name medical record number account numbers SSN date of birth and any other identifier
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA and HITECH: any health information in electronic format that can identify an individual including patient name medical record number account numbers SSN date of birth and any other identifier
protection_requirements: Encryption at rest (AES-256) and in transit (TLS 1.2+); access controls with MFA; audit logging (6+ years); regular risk assessment; incident response procedures; safeguard implementation per HIPAA Security Rule; business associate agreements for handling
minimum_safeguards: Encryption standards; Access control policies; Unique user identification; Role-based access control; Session timeouts; Audit logging; Encryption key management; Incident response procedures; Business associate agreements; Risk assessment
handling_restrictions: Restricted access only to authorized personnel with need-to-know; limited uses and disclosures; no disclosure without authorization except as permitted by law or individual consent; data minimization principle; secure transmission
retention_requirements: Retain for minimum 6 years for audit purposes; longer retention may be required for HIPAA documentation; business associate contracts require document retention
disposal_requirements: Secure deletion using NIST-approved methods; encryption key destruction; certified destruction procedures; documentation of destruction; no recovery possible after deletion
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Protection; Breach Notification; Business Associate Accountability; Encryption Standards; Access Controls; Audit Logging; Incident Response; Risk Assessment; Encryption; Safeguards Implementation
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13402 (Breach Notification); Section 13408 (BA Requirements); Section 13417 (Privacy/Security Enhancements)
examples: Patient medical records; Insurance claims; Prescription information; Lab results; Vital signs; Immunization records; Hospital discharge summaries; Psychiatric evaluations; Genetic information; Substance abuse treatment records; Any record with patient name or unique identifier linked to health data
key_identifiers: Name; Medical record number; Account number; Social Security number; Date of birth; Street address; Zip code; Phone number; Email address; Health plan beneficiary number; Insurance policy number; Employee ID; Employer name; Emergency contact information
compliance_obligations: Implement Privacy Rule restrictions on use and disclosure; Implement Security Rule technical physical and administrative safeguards; Maintain audit logs of all access; Conduct annual risk assessment; Provide privacy notices to individuals; Allow individual access and amendment rights; Report breaches to individuals HHS and media if 500+; Execute business associate agreements; Provide breach notification within 60 days
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR; State Attorneys General; Department of Justice (criminal); CMS (if EHR incentive program participant)

description: Health information from which all individual identifiers have been removed under HIPAA de-identification standards; no longer considered Protected Health Information and may be used and disclosed without restriction
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA 45 CFR 164.502(b): health information that does not identify an individual and cannot reasonably be used to identify an individual has been de-identified through removal of all 18 specific identifiers listed in HIPAA regulations
protection_requirements: While not subject to HIPAA restrictions after de-identification some safeguards recommended: general security practices; version control; source tracking; audit trail of de-identification process; verification documentation
breach_notification_required: No - de-identified data is not subject to HIPAA Breach Notification Rule and does not trigger breach notification obligations
minimum_safeguards: De-identification verification documentation; Safe harbor method verification (removal of 18 identifiers or statistical de-identification); Quality assurance procedures for de-identification process; Version control and tracking; Secure storage during de-identification process
handling_restrictions: No formal restrictions on use and disclosure once properly de-identified; can be used for research quality improvement operations and other purposes without individual consent; reasonable basis to believe re-identification is not possible
retention_requirements: Retain de-identification documentation for audit trail purposes; typical retention 2-3 years minimum for regulatory purposes; some research use may require longer retention
disposal_requirements: Standard data archival practices; destruction verification may be required for audit documentation; less stringent than EPHI disposal procedures; documentation of de-identification process retention adequate
domains_covered: Privacy & Security - De-identification; Research and Quality Improvement; Data Minimization; Regulatory Compliance
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13402 (Breach Notification - exemption); HIPAA 45 CFR 164.502(b); HIPAA 45 CFR Part 164 Appendix A (safe harbor method)
examples: Aggregate patient statistics; Research datasets with identifiers removed; Quality improvement data; Public health surveillance data; Clinical trial data after de-identification; Benchmark data for performance comparison; De-identified claims data
key_identifiers: No individual identifiers present; Aggregate statistics only; Statistical sufficiency maintained; List of 18 identifiers verified as removed; No reasonable basis to re-identify
compliance_obligations: Verify de-identification meets HIPAA safe harbor or statistical methods; Document de-identification process; Maintain audit trail; Establish reasonable basis that re-identification is not possible; Retain de-identification verification documentation; Conduct periodic quality assurance of de-identification procedures
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (for verification disputes); State Attorneys General (for misrepresentation); Department of Justice (if fraudulent misrepresentation)

description: Health information where personal identifiers have been replaced with a random code or pseudonym but linkage key exists that allows re-identification under controlled conditions; considered PHI and requires HIPAA protection even with identifiers replaced
regulatory_definition: Health information where identifiers have been replaced with a code or other proxy and remains potential to re-identify through linkage key management; retains PHI status for HIPAA purposes because re-identification remains possible
protection_requirements: Encryption for the data itself (AES-256 at rest TLS 1.2+ in transit); encryption of linkage key; separate secure storage of linkage key from pseudonymized data; access controls to both data and linkage key; dual control authentication for key access; audit logging of linkage key access; incident response procedures for both data and key
breach_notification_required: Yes - if linkage key is compromised or breaches occur pseudonymization integrity is violated and breach notification is triggered
minimum_safeguards: Encryption of data at rest and in transit; Encryption of linkage key; Separate secure storage of linkage key from data; Dual control authentication; Access logging to both data and linkage key; MFA for key access; Regular backup and testing of linkage key recovery; Incident response procedures; Business associate agreements if third party holds key or data
handling_restrictions: Restricted access to pseudonymized data limited to authorized research personnel; Access to linkage key limited to essential personnel only; Dual control requirement for key access; No disclosure of linkage key without authorization; Separation of duties between data handlers and key keepers; Regular audit of access patterns; Monitoring for suspicious access patterns
retention_requirements: Retain linkage key for duration of research study or project plus 6 years; De-identified data research use may continue after linkage key destruction; Retain audit logs of key access for 6+ years; Retention depends on research protocol and institutional policies
disposal_requirements: Secure destruction of linkage key when no longer needed; Pseudo-anonymized data can be retained longer after key destruction; Method: cryptographic erasure of keys using NIST-approved methods; Certification of key destruction; Documentation of destruction; Residual data testing
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Protection; Research Governance; Data Minimization; Breach Notification (if re-identification occurs); Access Control; Encryption; Key Management; Audit Logging
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions - PHI remains even with pseudonymization); Section 13402 (Breach Notification if re-identification); Section 13408 (BA Requirements if third-party holds data)
examples: Clinical trial participant data; Longitudinal research datasets; Electronic health record data for research use; Biobank specimens linked to health data; Multi-site research projects; Comparative effectiveness research; Post-marketing surveillance data; Registry data
key_identifiers: Linkage key maintained separately; Code or pseudonym substituted for identifiers; Re-identification possible through key; Access logs document key usage; Dual control enforced for key access; Audit trail of all key-related activities
compliance_obligations: Implement same Privacy and Security protections as EPHI for pseudonymized data; Protect linkage key equivalent to encryption keys; Implement dual-control access to linkage key; Maintain separate audit logs for data and key access; Conduct regular security assessments; Incident response plan for potential key compromise; Research institutional review board (IRB) approval; Data use agreements
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (for compliance with Privacy and Security Rules); State Attorneys General (for privacy violations); Department of Justice (for criminal violations); Institutional Review Boards (IRB) for research governance; Funding agencies (NIH NSF for research compliance)

description: Statistical summaries of health information that combine data from multiple individuals; no individual-level data present; summary statistics counts percentages averages across groups
regulatory_definition: Health information presented in summary form aggregated from multiple individuals in a manner that does not identify individuals or permit reasonable identification; generally not subject to HIPAA if properly aggregated but context and identifiability determination required
protection_requirements: General security practices for summary statistics; version control; source tracking; aggregate-level access controls; authentication for system access; basic audit logging of report generation
breach_notification_required: No - properly aggregated data is generally not subject to HIPAA Breach Notification if data cannot be linked back to individuals
minimum_safeguards: Verification procedures that aggregation meets HIPAA statistical standards; Documentation of aggregation methodology; Quality assurance for aggregate-level accuracy; Version control for statistical reports; Access controls to prevent report modification; Secure storage for confidentiality
handling_restrictions: No formal HIPAA restrictions on use if properly aggregated; can be used for benchmarking performance comparison research quality improvement and operations; disclosure generally permitted but consider state laws and contractual obligations
retention_requirements: Typical retention for operational data 2-3 years; research aggregate data longer retention as needed for research; audit trail of aggregation process retention 2-3 years minimum; compliance documentation may require longer retention
disposal_requirements: Standard archival and destruction procedures for statistical reports; destruction verification not required if no individual identifiers possible; documentation of aggregation methodology and verification retention adequate
domains_covered: Privacy & Security - Aggregation; Quality Improvement; Benchmarking; Research and Analytics; Performance Reporting; Comparative Analysis; Public Health Reporting
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions - analysis of de-identified or aggregated data not restricted); HIPAA 45 CFR 164.502(b) (aggregated data may not constitute PHI)
examples: Hospital readmission rates; Infection rates by department; Average length of stay statistics; Medication error rates; Patient satisfaction scores by department; Diagnostic code frequency distributions; Vaccination coverage percentages; Mortality statistics; Performance metrics for hospital accreditation; Benchmark data for comparative analysis
key_identifiers: No individual identifiers present; Aggregation meets statistical standards (typically minimum cell size of 5 or 10+); Suppression of small cell counts; Results cannot identify individuals; Sufficient group size to prevent inference
compliance_obligations: Verify aggregation meets HIPAA standards and produces results that do not identify individuals; Document aggregation methodology; Implement quality assurance for statistical accuracy; Maintain audit trail of report generation; Consider state laws on statistical data; Implement contractual protections; Regular review of aggregation procedures
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (if improper aggregation creates identifiability); State Attorneys General (state privacy law violations); Funding agencies (research compliance)

description: Any information about an individual's genetic composition or the genetic composition of biological relatives; includes genetic test results genetic predispositions family health history and genomic data; heightened sensitivity due to family implications
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA: health information that includes genetic data genetic test results genetic markers genetic profiles predictive genetic information and family genetic history that indicates genetic tests or conditions; HITECH and state genetic privacy laws add heightened protections
protection_requirements: Enhanced encryption (AES-256 at rest TLS 1.2+ in transit); more restrictive access controls than standard EPHI; genetic counselor review of access; dual authentication for genetic data access; genetic data segregation from other PHI; enhanced audit logging with specific tracking of genetic data access; incident response procedures specific to genetic breach; family notification protocols
breach_notification_required: Yes - within 60 days with specific genetic breach notification procedures; family members who may be affected should be considered for notification; enhanced notification requirements may apply
minimum_safeguards: Enhanced encryption for genetic data specifically; Segregated storage from other PHI where possible; Dual-factor authentication for access; Genetic counselor review and approval for access; Enhanced audit logging with specific genetic data access tracking; Annual risk assessment specific to genetic data; Genetic data-specific security policies; Enhanced incident response procedures; Mandatory genetic testing and re-confirmation if suspected breach
handling_restrictions: Highly restricted access - limited to: genetic counselors treating physicians and authorized researchers; Individual authorization generally required before access; Written consent for genetic research use; Genetic information disclosure prohibited without explicit authorization; No secondary uses without authorization; Family privacy considerations; Restrictions on genetic discrimination
retention_requirements: Retain genetic information longer than standard EPHI - typically lifetime for medical records; genetic data may remain relevant for family members into future; 6+ years minimum audit logs; genetic test results retained per state law which may exceed HIPAA requirements; research data retention per study protocol
disposal_requirements: Enhanced destruction procedures for genetic data; Cryptographic erasure required for genetic data backup; Certified destruction with specific genetic data verification; No recovery possible after destruction; Family privacy considerations in destruction; Documentation of destruction with genetic-specific details
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Protection - Genetic Data; Genetic Privacy; Family Privacy Protection; Genetic Discrimination Prevention; Informed Consent; Research Governance; Breach Notification - Genetic Data; Access Control - Genetic Data; Genetic Information Segregation
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions - genetic data is PHI); Section 13402 (Breach Notification); Section 13417 (Enhanced Privacy/Security protections); State Genetic Privacy Laws; Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA); 42 USC 1320d-9
examples: Genetic test results; DNA sequencing results; Genetic predisposition information; Family health history indicating genetic tests; Carrier status information; Pathogenic variant information; Ethnic origin (genomic); Genomic biomarkers; Genetic risk scores; Whole genome sequencing data; Exome sequencing data
key_identifiers: Genetic markers; Gene mutations; SNP data; Genetic predisposition indicators; Pathogenic variants; Family relationship to tested individual; Ethnic genomic origin; Genetic test type and date; Laboratory-specific genetic nomenclature; Genetic risk assessment results
compliance_obligations: Implement enhanced privacy and security protections beyond standard HIPAA; Obtain explicit informed consent for genetic testing and use; Restrict genetic information use to treatment unless consent obtained for research; Implement genetic-specific access controls; Segregate genetic data from other PHI where feasible; Conduct annual genetic data security assessments; Provide genetic counseling for results interpretation; Family notification protocols for genetic findings; Ensure GINA compliance to prevent genetic discrimination; Monitor for unauthorized access to genetic data; Implement genetic data retention and destruction policies that exceed standard HIPAA timelines
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (HIPAA genetic privacy enforcement); State genetic privacy boards; State Attorneys General (genetic privacy violations); EEOC (GINA - genetic discrimination); Department of Labor (GINA - employer coverage); CMS (if EHR program participant)

description: Unique physical and behavioral characteristics used for identification purposes; includes fingerprints iris scans facial recognition voice recognition gait analysis and other biometric identifiers; increasingly used in healthcare for authentication and identification
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA: biometric information that can identify an individual or link to individual health records; used for authentication access control and identification in healthcare systems; heightened sensitivity as biometric data cannot be changed like passwords
protection_requirements: Encryption at rest and in transit (standard EPHI level); biometric template encryption preferred to raw biometric data; multi-factor authentication for biometric system access; regular biometric system audits; biometric data segregation from other PHI; audit logging of all biometric authentication events; incident response specific to biometric data; secure backup and recovery procedures for biometric systems
breach_notification_required: Yes - if biometric authentication systems are compromised or biometric data is disclosed; biometric breach may be more serious than password breach as cannot be changed; notification within 60 days required
minimum_safeguards: Encryption of biometric data and templates; Secure biometric system architecture; Tamper-proof audit logging of biometric authentication; Multi-factor authentication for biometric system administration; Regular biometric system penetration testing; Backup procedures with encryption; Secure key management for biometric encryption; Physical security of biometric sensors and systems; Network segmentation for biometric systems
handling_restrictions: Restricted access to biometric data only for authentication system administration; No secondary uses of biometric data without authorization; Prohibition on sharing biometric data with third parties; Limited retention - biometric templates should be destroyed when authentication no longer needed; Regular audits for unauthorized biometric template creation or use; Biometric data cannot be used for other purposes without explicit consent
retention_requirements: Retain biometric templates only as long as authentication access is needed; Destroy biometric templates when access is terminated; Audit logs of biometric authentication retain 6+ years per HIPAA audit requirements; Biometric system backups retain minimum 6 months; Research use of biometric data prohibits long-term retention
disposal_requirements: Cryptographic erasure of biometric templates when no longer needed; Certified destruction of biometric backup data; Verification procedures for biometric destruction; No recovery of destroyed biometric data; Documentation of biometric destruction; Physical destruction of hardware containing biometric data if decommissioned
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Protection - Biometric Data; Access Control - Biometric Authentication; Data Segregation; Audit Logging - Biometric Events; Incident Response - Biometric Breach; Physical Security; Biometric System Management; Cyber Security
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions - biometric as unique identifier); Section 13402 (Breach Notification); Section 13408 (Security safeguards for biometric systems); Section 13417 (Enhanced security for biometric technology)
examples: Fingerprint authentication in EHR systems; Iris scanning for hospital access control; Facial recognition in patient identification systems; Voice recognition for voice-based EHR access; Gait recognition for continuous authentication; Retinal scans for secure access; Hand geometry readers in secure areas; Palm vein recognition for patient identification; Fingerprint templates in credentialing systems; Multi-modal biometric systems combining multiple biometric types
key_identifiers: Fingerprints; Iris patterns; Facial geometry; Voice characteristics; Gait patterns; Retinal patterns; Hand geometry; Palm vein patterns; Behavioral biometrics (keyboard dynamics); DNA (special biometric); Biometric template; Biometric hash; Biometric encryption key
compliance_obligations: Implement enhanced encryption for biometric data; Segregate biometric data from other PHI where feasible; Conduct annual security assessments specific to biometric systems; Implement tamper-proof audit logging; Require multi-factor authentication for biometric system access; Establish procedures to prevent misidentification or false matches affecting healthcare; Monitor for unauthorized access to biometric data; Implement procedures to handle biometric authentication failures; Contractual protections with biometric system vendors; Regular biometric system penetration testing; Biometric destruction procedures when access terminated
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (HIPAA security and privacy enforcement for biometric systems); State Attorneys General (state biometric privacy laws); FBI (if criminal biometric data theft); CMS (if EHR incentive program participant); Federal Trade Commission (FTC - if consumer privacy violations)

description: Protected Health Information that has not been protected by encryption or other approved safeguards as defined by HITECH Act; if breached triggers mandatory breach notification; may result in civil penalties criminal prosecution and OCR enforcement action
regulatory_definition: Under HITECH Section 13400: PHI that is not secured through encryption or destruction according to NIST standards and HHS guidance; absence of safeguards that meets HIPAA Security Rule requirements; presumed to be compromised if unauthorized acquisition occurs unless entity demonstrates otherwise through risk assessment
protection_requirements: Immediate implementation of encryption (AES-256 at rest TLS 1.2+ in transit); implement all HIPAA Security Rule safeguards retroactively; conduct forensic assessment; data inventory and flow mapping; asset inventory; vulnerability scanning; penetration testing; incident response activation; breach notification procedures; Corrective Action Plan development
breach_notification_required: Yes - 60-day notification mandatory without exception; notification to affected individuals media HHS; Tier 4 penalties likely apply; OCR enforcement action triggered
minimum_safeguards: IMMEDIATE: Implement encryption standards (AES-256 TLS 1.2+); Implement access controls with MFA; Implement audit logging; Risk assessment and remediation; Incident response procedures; Corrective Action Plan with OCR monitoring; Vulnerability remediation; System hardening; Staff training on security; Business associate audit and agreements review
handling_restrictions: Immediate prohibition on further unsecured transmission or storage; Unsecured PHI must be secured immediately or destroyed; Access restrictions while remediation occurs; Secure backup and redundancy implementation; Network segmentation to isolate unsecured systems; Temporary enhanced monitoring during remediation; Restricted access to unsecured systems
retention_requirements: Retain inventory of unsecured PHI and remediation activities for minimum 6 years for audit and legal discovery purposes; Enhanced documentation for regulatory proceedings; Evidence preservation for potential enforcement action or litigation
disposal_requirements: Secure destruction required for unsecured PHI; Cryptographic erasure if in digital form; Certified destruction procedures; No recovery possible; Forensic verification of destruction; Chain of custody documentation; Legal hold if breach investigation ongoing
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Protection; Breach Notification - Mandatory; Enforcement & Penalties; Risk Assessment; Corrective Action Plans; Incident Response - Emergency Response; OCR Enforcement; Criminal Investigation; Civil Litigation; Safe Harbor Evaluation
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definition of unsecured PHI - breach presumed compromised); Section 13402 (Breach Notification mandatory); Section 13406 (Civil penalties Tier 4 - $20K-$50K minimum); Section 13409 (Criminal penalties); Section 13418 (Safe Harbor - if security practices implemented); NIST SP 800-88 (Secure Deletion Guidelines); HHS 45 CFR 164.308(a)(7)
examples: Patient lists in unencrypted spreadsheets; Unencrypted email containing PHI; Unencrypted portable devices (USB drives laptops tablets); Unencrypted personal computers; Unencrypted mobile phones; Unencrypted cloud storage; Paper records lost or stolen; Records sent via unencrypted fax; Verbal information overheard; Unsecured databases; Unencrypted server backups; EHR systems with weak passwords; Systems with default credentials; Networks with no firewalls; Systems without access controls
key_identifiers: Identifiable health information in unencrypted form; Absence of encryption that meets NIST standards; Absence of other approved safeguards per HHS guidance; Unauthorized access or acquisition; Evidence of compromise; Forensic findings of improper access; Detection of unauthorized data exfiltration
compliance_obligations: Implement encryption immediately (within 24-48 hours if feasible); Assess scope of unsecured PHI; Notify HHS OCR if 500+ individuals affected; Develop comprehensive security remediation plan; Implement Corrective Action Plan; Cooperate with OCR investigation; Prepare for penalties; Document remediation efforts; Preserve evidence; Conduct breach investigation; Provide breach notification to affected individuals; Consider voluntary disclosure to OCR if breach discovered internally; Implement comprehensive security assessment; Address root causes; Retrain staff on security requirements; Audit business associates for similar exposures
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (primary enforcement - significant penalties); State Attorneys General (civil damages); Department of Justice (criminal prosecution - knowingly); Federal Trade Commission (consumer protection); Plaintiffs bar (civil litigation); Regulatory agencies (state health departments); Media (public breach notification)

description: Health information combined with financial information such as payment method billing address insurance policy numbers payment amounts and healthcare costs; triggers both HIPAA and financial security regulations
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA and supplemental financial privacy regulations: PHI combined with financial data; subject to HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules plus additional protections for financial information under GLBA Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act; heightened protection when PHI linked to payment systems
protection_requirements: Encryption at rest and in transit (standard HIPAA level); additionally: PCI DSS compliance if payment card data involved; encryption of financial credentials; separation of financial data from other PHI where feasible; additional access controls for financial data; enhanced audit logging of financial transactions; fraud detection and monitoring; three-factor authentication for financial transactions
breach_notification_required: Yes - 60-day breach notification required; may also trigger notification under payment card industry standards; potential SEC notification if material financial breach; OCR and financial regulator enforcement
minimum_safeguards: Encryption per HIPAA and PCI DSS standards; Encryption of payment card data (CVV expiration date); Network segmentation for payment systems; Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) compliance; End-to-end encryption for payment transactions; Key management separate from data; Enhanced access controls for financial systems; Fraud detection and monitoring; Regular penetration testing of payment systems; Secure backup of financial data with encryption; Incident response for financial data breaches
handling_restrictions: Restricted access to financial PHI limited to financial staff and authorized personnel; No disclosure of financial data to clinical staff without authorization; Restrictions on secondary use of financial data; Payment information must be handled per PCI DSS; Audit of financial data access; Monitoring for suspicious financial transactions; Restrictions on sale of financial data; Credit card data expiration dates; Account numbers never stored without encryption
retention_requirements: Financial records retain 6+ years minimum per federal tax and healthcare regulations; Payment records retain 5-7 years per IRS requirements; Health insurance records retain 3+ years per HIPAA; Audit logs of financial transactions retain 6+ years; PCI DSS compliance may require longer retention; Research use of financial data restricted
disposal_requirements: Secure destruction of financial data per NIST and PCI DSS standards; Payment card data must be irrevocably destroyed; Cryptographic erasure of financial credentials; Certified destruction procedures; No recovery of destroyed financial data; Chain of custody for destruction; Documentation of financial data destruction; Compliance certification with PCI DSS destruction requirements
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Protection - Financial Data; Breach Notification; Financial Privacy; PCI Compliance; Payment System Security; Fraud Prevention; Access Control - Financial Data; Encryption - Payment Data; Audit Logging - Financial Transactions; Regulatory Compliance - Financial
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions - PHI includes financial PHI); Section 13402 (Breach Notification); Section 13408 (Security requirements); Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA); Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS); State financial privacy laws
examples: Insurance claim information with patient SSN; Patient billing records with payment method; Credit card information for patient payments; Account numbers for patient accounts; Healthcare cost data linked to patient identity; Insurance policy numbers with health information; Payment authorization records; Billing history with health diagnoses; Patient financial responsibility statements; Medicare/Medicaid enrollment data linked to claims
key_identifiers: Payment card number; Expiration date; CVV security code; Bank account number; Routing number; Insurance policy number; Patient account number linked to payment; Authorization code; Payment amount; Healthcare cost associated with identity; Insurance claim linked to patient; Billing address; Employer information; Credit score (if in system)
compliance_obligations: Implement HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules; Comply with PCI DSS if handling payment cards; Encrypt financial data at rest and in transit; Segregate financial data from clinical PHI where possible; Implement access controls restricting financial data to authorized staff; Maintain audit logs of all financial data access; Implement fraud detection and monitoring; Conduct annual security assessment; Implement payment system penetration testing; Vendor management for payment processors; Business associate agreements must address financial data; Secure backup procedures; Incident response for financial data breaches; PCI DSS assessment and certification; Report suspected fraud; Data minimization - collect only necessary financial data
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (HIPAA enforcement); State Attorneys General (financial privacy); Payment Card Industry (PCI DSS enforcement); Federal Trade Commission (financial fraud); Financial regulatory agencies (SEC; FDIC; OCC for financial institutions); Plaintiffs bar (civil litigation for financial data breaches); State Attorneys General (consumer protection)

description: Health information related to substance abuse diagnosis treatment or referral; specifically protected under 42 CFR Part 2 federal substance abuse confidentiality law; heightened protections beyond standard HIPAA
regulatory_definition: Under 42 CFR Part 2: records of the identity diagnosis prognosis treatment and referral of any patient who has applied for or been provided treatment for alcohol or drug abuse; federal law creates additional confidentiality requirements beyond HIPAA
protection_requirements: Encryption at rest and in transit (AES-256 TLS 1.2+); additional requirement: physical separation from general medical records where feasible; restricted access to substance abuse records requiring written consent; additional documentation requirements; locked storage if paper records; restricted sharing - prohibition on sharing with law enforcement without valid court order; restricted access logging; mandatory staff training on 42 CFR Part 2; breach procedures specific to substance abuse records
breach_notification_required: Yes - 60-day notification required AND additional notification to substance abuse-specific regulatory agencies (SAMHSA); potential criminal penalties under 42 CFR Part 2 for improper disclosure; breach may result in loss of federal funding for substance abuse programs
minimum_safeguards: Encryption at rest and in transit; Segregation from general medical records (physical or logical); Access restricted to treatment providers and authorized staff; Written consent documentation for any disclosure; Strict access logging with 42 CFR Part 2 documentation; Mandatory staff training on 42 CFR Part 2 confidentiality requirements; Physical security (locked storage for paper records); Secure disposal procedures specific to substance abuse records; Business associate agreements with strict substance abuse confidentiality clauses; Regular audits for unauthorized access; Incident response procedures
handling_restrictions: Highly restricted - disclosure only with patient written consent OR pursuant to court order OR to personnel conducting research approved by Institutional Review Board (IRB) OR for audits and inspections OR in medical emergency; Prohibition on disclosure to law enforcement; Prohibition on use for criminal investigation or prosecution; Prohibition on disclosure to employer insurance company or other third parties; Restrictions on re-disclosure; Segregated consent forms required; Detailed access log maintenance
retention_requirements: Retain substance abuse treatment records minimum 7+ years for federal compliance; Longer retention may be required for ongoing treatment; Audit logs of substance abuse record access retain 6+ years minimum; Documentation of written consents retain minimum 7 years; Federal substance abuse program records may have even longer retention requirements
disposal_requirements: Secure destruction of substance abuse records per 42 CFR Part 2 requirements; Cryptographic erasure for digital records; Certified destruction procedures with documentation; Chain of custody for destruction; Destruction must be verifiable and irreversible; Fire destruction or secure shredding for paper records; Certification of destruction; Documentation retained for audit purposes
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Protection - Substance Abuse; Federal Substance Abuse Confidentiality; Breach Notification - Substance Abuse; Law Enforcement Restrictions; Research Governance - Substance Abuse; Informed Consent - Substance Abuse Treatment; Access Control - Substance Abuse Records; Segregation - Substance Abuse Data; Audit Logging - Substance Abuse Access; Criminal Liability Prevention
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13402 (Breach Notification); 42 CFR Part 2 (Federal substance abuse confidentiality law); 42 USC 290dd-2 (Confidentiality of substance abuse records); State substance abuse confidentiality laws; SAMHSA regulations
examples: Substance abuse diagnosis codes; Treatment records from addiction medicine; Methadone maintenance treatment records; Counseling records for substance abuse; Medication-assisted treatment records; Rehabilitation facility records; Psychiatric records mentioning substance abuse; Lab tests ordered specifically for substance abuse treatment monitoring; Referrals to substance abuse programs; Discharge summaries from substance abuse treatment; Prescription records for controlled substances for treatment
key_identifiers: Diagnosis of substance abuse; Treatment provider identity; Patient identity; Treatment plans; Medications prescribed; Referral information; Counselor identity; Group therapy attendance; Drug screen results; Length of treatment; Treatment modality; Prognosis; Payment method for treatment
compliance_obligations: Implement HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules PLUS 42 CFR Part 2 requirements; Segregate substance abuse records from general medical records physically or logically; Restrict access to substance abuse records; Require written consent for any disclosure of substance abuse information; Implement separate audit logs for substance abuse record access; Document all written consents for disclosure; Comply with prohibition on disclosure to law enforcement without court order; Train all staff on 42 CFR Part 2 confidentiality requirements; Implement strict access controls; Maintain separate incident response procedures for substance abuse breaches; Business associate agreements must address 42 CFR Part 2; Implement federal compliance audit programs; Report any breaches to SAMHSA and HHS OCR
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (HIPAA enforcement for substance abuse records); SAMHSA (42 CFR Part 2 enforcement); State Attorneys General (federal confidentiality violations); Department of Justice (criminal prosecution for improper disclosure); Federal courts (enforcement of 42 CFR Part 2 protections); Plaintiffs bar (civil litigation); Patients (private right of action under 42 CFR Part 2)

description: Health information related to mental health diagnosis treatment or counseling records; often subject to heightened privacy protections under state laws and HIPAA psychotherapist-patient privilege
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA and state mental health confidentiality laws: records of mental health treatment psychiatric counseling psychiatric diagnoses treatment plans and psychotherapy notes; subject to HIPAA plus heightened state protections and psychotherapist-patient privilege
protection_requirements: Encryption at rest and in transit (AES-256 TLS 1.2+); segregation from general medical records where feasible (physical or logical); restricted access requiring clinical or administrative need; documentation of access; psychotherapy notes stored separately with additional protections; restricted sharing - enhanced consent requirements; staff training on mental health confidentiality; incident response procedures
breach_notification_required: Yes - 60-day notification required; breach of mental health records may have heightened impact and enhanced notification procedures; potential state reporting requirements; may affect psychiatric treatment relationships; greater reputational harm
minimum_safeguards: Encryption at rest and in transit; Segregation of psychotherapy notes if possible; Restricted access requiring documented clinical or administrative need; Enhanced access logging and monitoring; Staff training on mental health confidentiality and privilege; Separate consent documentation; Limitations on disclosure to non-treatment personnel; Additional protections for psychotherapy notes (not used for treatment decisions or covered under privilege); Restricted sharing with research entities; Business associate agreements with mental health-specific confidentiality requirements; Regular access audits
handling_restrictions: Restricted to treatment providers and authorized clinical staff; Professional use limitations for administrative staff; Restrictions on secondary use; Prohibition on disclosure to third parties without informed consent; Limitations on disclosure to law enforcement; Separate consent forms required for specialty uses; Restrictions on insurance company access; No use for employment determination; State law protections for particularly sensitive information
retention_requirements: Retain mental health records minimum 6+ years per HIPAA; Longer retention per state law which may exceed HIPAA timelines; Psychotherapy notes may require longer retention (7-10+ years) per clinical judgment; Audit logs retain 6+ years; Documentation of consents retain minimum 6 years
disposal_requirements: Secure destruction per HIPAA and state law requirements; Enhanced destruction for psychotherapy notes if applicable; Cryptographic erasure for digital records; Certified destruction procedures with documentation; Chain of custody; No recovery of destroyed records; Paper records secure shredding or fire destruction; Destruction certification
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Protection - Mental Health; Psychotherapist-Patient Privilege; Breach Notification - Mental Health; Informed Consent - Mental Health; Research Governance - Mental Health; Segregation - Mental Health Records; Access Control - Mental Health Records; Audit Logging - Mental Health Access; State Confidentiality Laws - Mental Health
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13402 (Breach Notification); HIPAA Privacy Rule psychotherapy notes exception (45 CFR 164.508); State mental health confidentiality laws; Court ordered protections; Patient privacy rights; Psychotherapist-patient privilege
examples: Psychiatric diagnosis records; Psychotherapy notes; Counseling session records; Treatment plans from psychiatry; Medications prescribed for mental health; Psychiatric hospital records; Group therapy attendance; Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) records; Psychological testing results; Mental health screening results; Crisis intervention records; Suicide risk assessment; Behavioral health notes
key_identifiers: Psychiatric diagnosis; Treatment provider identity; Mental health condition description; Psychotherapy content; Medication regimen; Patient statements/disclosures; Risk factors identified; Treatment modality; Provider notes and impressions; Patient goals and progress; Referrals; Family information
compliance_obligations: Implement HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules with heightened mental health protections; Segregate psychotherapy notes if feasible; Restrict access to mental health records; Implement enhanced consent procedures; Document clinical or administrative need for access; Maintain separate audit logs for mental health record access; Comply with state mental health confidentiality laws; Protect psychotherapist-patient privilege; Implement staff training on mental health confidentiality; Implement procedures for managing sensitive disclosures; Business associate agreements must address mental health confidentiality; Coordinate with law enforcement requests to ensure legal basis; Implement breach response procedures specific to mental health records; Consider impact on ongoing treatment
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (HIPAA enforcement); State Attorneys General (state mental health privacy laws); State medical boards (professional license protection); Plaintiffs bar (civil litigation); Psychotherapy licensing boards; Patients (private right of action); Courts (psychotherapist-patient privilege enforcement)
